text: Induction of activator protein ( AP ) -1 and nuclear factor-kappaB by <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> stimulation involves both phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase and <extra_id_0> acidic sphingomyelinase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signals .

A major obstacle in understanding the signaling events that follow <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> receptor ligation arises from the fact that <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> acts as a costimulus to TCR engagement , making it difficult to assess the relative contribution of <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signals as distinct from those of the TCR .

To overcome this problem , we have exploited the observation that activated human T cell blasts can be stimulated via the <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> surface molecule in the absence of antigenic challenge ; thus , we have been able to observe the response of normal T cells to <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation in isolation .

Using this system , we observed that <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> stimulation by <extra_id_0> B7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - transfected CHO cells induced a proliferative response in T cells that was not accompanied by measurable <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production .

text: However , subsequent analysis of transcription factor generation revealed that <extra_id_0> B7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> stimulation induced both activator protein - 1 ( AP-1 ) and nuclear factor-kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) complexes , but not NF-AT .

In contrast , engagement of the TCR by class II MHC / superantigen , either with or without <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ligation , resulted in the induction of NF-AT , AP-1 , and NF-kappaB as well as <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production .

text: Using selective inhibitors , we investigated the signaling pathways involved in the <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated induction of AP-1 and NF-kappaB .

This revealed that NF-kappaB generation was sensitive to chloroquine , an inhibitor of <extra_id_0> acidic sphingomyelinase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , but not to the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase inhibitor , wortmannin .
In contrast , AP-1 generation was inhibited by wortmannin and was also variably sensitive to chloroquine .

These data suggest that in activated normal T cells , <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - derived signals can stimulate proliferation at least in part via NF-kappaB and AP-1 generation , and that this response uses both <extra_id_0> acidic sphingomyelinase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase - linked pathways .
